title: Architecture
content: Architecture High-level architecture and design principles of govman. System Overview govman is a command-line tool for managing multiple Go versions with automatic version switching support. Design Goals 1. Simple: Easy to install and use 2. Fast: Quick downloads, efficient switching 3. Reliable: Verified downloads, atomic operations 4. Cross-platform: Works on Linux, macOS, Windows 5. Shell-agnostic: Supports Bash, Zsh, Fish, PowerShell Architecture Layers Layer Responsibilities 1. CLI Layer ( ) Purpose: User interaction and command handling Responsibilities: - Parse command-line arguments - Validate user input - Display formatted output - Handle errors gracefully - Show progress indicators Key Components: - Root command initialization - Subcommand registration - Flag parsing - Output formatting - Help text generation Example: 2. Manager Layer ( ) Purpose: Business logic orchestration Responsibilities: - Coordinate between services - Implement workflows - Handle transactions - Manage state - Error recovery Key Operations: - - Download, verify, extract, install - - Remove version and clean up - - Switch active version - - Query installed/remote versions - - Get active version Example: 3. Service Layer Config Service ( ) Purpose: Configuration management Features: - YAML configuration loading - Default values - Path expansion - Validation - Directory creation Configuration Structure: yaml autoswitch: enabled: true projectfile: .govman-version Downloader Service ( ) Purpose: Download and extract Go distributions Features: - HTTP downloads with resume support - SHA-256 verification - Archive extraction (tar.gz, zip) - Progress reporting - Retry with backoff - Path traversal protection Download Flow: Golang API Service ( ) Purpose: Interact with Go releases API Features: - Fetch available versions - Parse release metadata - Version comparison - Platform-specific file selection - Cache management API Integration: Shell Service ( ) Purpose: Shell-specific integration Features: - Shell detection (Bash, Zsh, Fish, PowerShell) - Configuration file management - PATH manipulation - Auto-switch hooks - Initialization code generation Shell Interface: Example Implementation: Symlink Service ( ) Purpose: Manage symbolic links Features: - Create symlinks - Read symlink targets - Cross-platform support - Atomic updates Key Design Patterns 1. Layered Architecture Each layer depends only on layers below it: Benefits: - Clear separation of concerns - Easy to test individual layers - Can swap implementations 2. Dependency Injection Services are injected into Manager: Benefits: - Easy to mock for testing - Configurable behavior - Loose coupling 3. Strategy Pattern (Shell Integration) Different shells implement common interface: 4. Singleton Pattern (Logger) Global logger instance: 5. Factory Pattern (Progress Bars) Create progress bars based on context: 6. Builder Pattern (HTTP Requests) Build complex requests: Error Handling Strategy Error Wrapping Always wrap errors with context: Error Recovery Manager handles rollback on failure: User-Friendly Errors Logger provides helpful error messages: Concurrency Model Thread Safety Manager uses mutex for critical sections: Concurrent Downloads Future: Support parallel downloads: State Management Version State Tracked via filesystem: Configuration State Stored in YAML: Shell State Maintained in shell config: Performance Considerations 1. Caching - Release data cached for 1 hour - Downloaded archives kept in cache - Symlinks for fast switching 2. Incremental Operations - Resume interrupted downloads - Skip re-download if cached - Atomic symlink updates 3. Efficient Extraction - Stream extraction (no double disk usage) - Skip unnecessary files - Parallel extraction (future) 4. Minimal Overhead - Auto-switch checks are fast (<1ms) - Lazy initialization - No background processes Security Considerations 1. Checksum Verification Always verify SHA-256: 2. Path Traversal Prevention Validate all paths: 3. HTTPS Only All downloads use HTTPS: 4. Minimal Permissions Files created with restrictive permissions: Extensibility Adding New Shells 1. Implement interface 2. Add detection logic 3. Register in factory Adding New Commands 1. Create command file in 2. Implement command logic 3. Register in Adding New Configuration Options 1. Update struct 2. Add default value 3. Document in See Also - Project Structure - Code organization - Data Flow - How data moves - Architecture Diagrams - Visual representation --- Understanding the architecture helps you contribute effectively! ðŸ—ï¸

Usage Description Shows detailed information about the active Go version: - Version number - Installation path - Platform (OS/architecture) - Installation date - Disk usage - Activation method Examples Output Activation Methods - - Temporary terminal activation - - Via file - - Via default configuration --- govman list List installed or available Go versions. Usage Flags Aliases Description Lists Go versions either: - Local: Installed on your system - Remote: Available for installation Examples Output: Installed Versions Output: Remote Versions --- govman info Show detailed information about a specific Go version. Usage Arguments Description Displays comprehensive details about an installed Go version: - Version and status - Platform information - Installation path - Installation date and age - Disk usage - Activation suggestions Examples Output For Inactive Versions --- govman clean Clean download cache to free disk space. Usage Description Removes cached download files: - Downloaded Go archives (.tar.gz, .zip) - Temporary extraction directories - Incomplete or corrupted downloads - Cache metadata Safe operation: - âœ… Installed Go versions remain untouched - âœ… Your projects and configurations preserved - âœ… Only temporary cache files removed Examples What It Does 1. Scans for removable files 2. Removes all cached archives 3. Removes temporary files 4. Reports freed disk space Output When to Use - After installing multiple versions - When disk space is low - Before backing up your system - Periodically for maintenance --- govman refresh Re-evaluate current directory for version switching. Usage Description Manually triggers version switching based on current directory: - Checks for file - Switches to specified version if found - Falls back to default version if not found Equivalent to the auto-switch that happens automatically with shell integration. content: Dependencies Complete reference for govman's external and internal dependencies. Direct Dependencies CLI Framework cobra (github.com/spf13/cobra) - Version: v1.8.0+ - Purpose: Command-line interface framework - Usage: Command structure, flags, subcommands - License: Apache 2.0 Key Features Used: - Root command and subcommands - Flag parsing (global and local flags) - Command aliases - Help generation - Completion generation Example: viper (github.com/spf13/viper) - Version: v1.18.0+ - Purpose: Configuration management - Usage: YAML config file reading/writing - License: MIT Key Features Used: - YAML configuration - Environment variable binding - Default values - Configuration validation Example: Compression and Archives compress/gzip (standard library) - Purpose: Gzip decompression for .tar.gz files - Usage: Extract downloaded Go distributions archive/tar (standard library) - Purpose: TAR archive extraction - Usage: Extract .tar.gz archives (Unix/Linux/macOS) archive/zip (standard library) - Purpose: ZIP archive extraction - Usage: Extract .zip archives (Windows) HTTP Client net/http (standard library) - Purpose: HTTP downloads - Usage: Download Go distributions and release data Features Used: - GET requests with custom headers - Range requests for resume - Progress tracking - Timeout handling - Redirect following Example: Cryptography crypto/sha256 (standard library) - Purpose: SHA-256 checksum verification - Usage: Verify downloaded file integrity Example: JSON Processing encoding/json (standard library) - Purpose: JSON parsing - Usage: Parse Go releases API response Example: File System Operations os (standard library) - Purpose: File and directory operations - Usage: File creation, deletion, symlinks path/filepath (standard library) - Purpose: Path manipulation - Usage: Path joining, cleaning, directory traversal io (standard library) - Purpose: I/O operations - Usage: File copying, reading, writing Process Execution os/exec (standard library) - Purpose: Execute external commands - Usage: Run shell commands for PATH setup Example: Concurrency sync (standard library) - Purpose: Synchronization primitives - Usage: Singleton logger, mutex for thread safety Example: Runtime Detection runtime (standard library) - Purpose: Platform detection - Usage: Determine OS and architecture Example: Version Comparison golang.org/x/mod/semver - Version: v0.14.0+ - Purpose: Semantic version comparison - Usage: Compare Go versions (1.20.1 vs 1.21.0) - License: BSD-3-Clause Example: Development Dependencies Testing testing (standard library) - Purpose: Unit tests - Usage: All files Example: testify (github.com/stretchr/testify) - Version: v1.8.0+ (optional) - Purpose: Test assertions and mocking - Usage: Enhanced test readability - License: MIT Example: Build Tools Make - Purpose: Build automation - Usage: Makefile for common tasks Targets: - - Build binary - - Run tests - - Install locally - - Clean build artifacts Indirect Dependencies These are dependencies of our direct dependencies (transitive): From cobra/viper: - - Windows compatibility - - POSIX/GNU-style flags - - YAML parsing - - File watching - - HCL support - - Properties file support - - TOML support - - .env file support From golang.org/x/mod: - - Error handling Standard Library Dependencies Complete list of standard library packages used: | Package | Purpose | |---------|---------| | | TAR extraction | | | ZIP extraction | | | Gzip decompression | | | Context management | | | SHA-256 hashing | | | Hexadecimal encoding | | | JSON parsing | | | Error handling | | | Formatting | | | I/O operations | | | I/O utilities | | | HTTP client | | | OS interface | | | Process execution | | | Path manipulation | | | Runtime info | | | String utilities | | | Synchronization | | | Time operations | Dependency Management go.mod Updating Dependencies Vendoring (Optional) External APIs Go Download API Endpoint: Purpose: Fetch available Go versions Response Format: Rate Limiting: None specified, but cached locally Caching: 1 hour (configurable) Go Binary Downloads Endpoint: Example: Mirror Support: Configurable mirror URLs Dependency Security Vulnerability Scanning Checksum Verification All dependencies are verified via : Supply Chain Security - All dependencies are from trusted sources - Go module proxy provides integrity verification - HTTPS for all downloads - SHA-256 checksums for Go distributions Dependency Licenses | Package | License | Commercial Use | |---------|---------|----------------| | cobra | Apache 2.0 | âœ… Yes | | viper | MIT | âœ… Yes | | golang.org/x/mod | BSD-3-Clause | âœ… Yes | | Go standard library | BSD-3-Clause | âœ… Yes | All dependencies are permissively licensed and safe for commercial use. Minimal Dependency Philosophy govman follows a minimal dependency approach: Why Minimal Dependencies? 1. Security: Fewer dependencies = smaller attack surface 2. Reliability: Less risk of breakage from updates 3. Performance: Smaller binary size 4. Maintenance: Fewer updates needed Dependencies We Avoided - UI frameworks: Used standard output instead - HTTP libraries: Standard is sufficient - Logging frameworks: Built custom lightweight logger - Configuration libraries: Viper handles our needs - Progress bars: Built custom implementation When We Add Dependencies Only when: 1. Feature requires complex implementation 2. Standard library doesn't provide functionality 3. Dependency is well-maintained and widely used 4. License is permissive Binary Size Impact | Component | Size Contribution | |-----------|-------------------| | Go standard library | ~1.2 MB | | cobra | ~500 KB | | viper | ~800 KB | | golang.org/x/mod | ~100 KB | | govman code | ~300 KB | | Total | ~3 MB | Stripped and compressed: ~2 MB Version Compatibility Go Version Requirements - Minimum: Go 1.20 - Recommended: Go 1.21+ - Tested: Go 1.20, 1.21, 1.22 Dependency Version Strategy - Use stable versions (no pre-releases) - Pin major versions to avoid breaking changes - Test before upgrading major versions - Keep dependencies reasonably up-to-date for security See Also - Project Structure - Code organization - Architecture - System design - Getting Started - Development setup --- Understanding dependencies helps with security, maintenance, and troubleshooting! ðŸ“¦

title: Project Structure
content: Project Structure Understanding the govman codebase organization and architecture. Directory Overview Core Components 1. Entry Point ( ) Purpose: Application initialization Files: Minimal entry point that: - Calls - Handles top-level errors - Sets exit codes 2. CLI Layer ( ) Purpose: User interface and command handling Key Files: - - Root command, banner, config initialization - - Command registration and global flags - - Individual command implementations Responsibilities: - Parse command-line arguments - Display user-friendly output - Call Manager for business logic - Handle errors gracefully 3. Manager ( ) Purpose: Core business logic orchestration Key File: Main Functions: - - Download and install Go versions - - Remove installed versions - - Switch between versions - - Get active version - - List local versions - - Fetch available versions Coordinates: - Configuration - Downloader - Shell integration - Symlink management 4. Configuration ( ) Purpose: Configuration management Key File: Features: - YAML-based configuration - Default values - Path expansion and validation - Security checks (path traversal prevention) - Config file creation and updates 5. Downloader ( ) Purpose: Download and extract Go distributions Key File: Capabilities: - HTTP downloads with retry logic - Resume interrupted downloads - SHA-256 checksum verification - Archive extraction (.tar.gz, .zip) - Path traversal protection - Progress reporting 6. Go Releases ( ) Purpose: Go version information and comparison Key File: Functions: - Fetch available versions from go.dev - Parse and cache version data - Compare semantic versions - Generate download URLs - Extract version metadata 7. Shell Integration ( ) Purpose: Shell-specific integration Key File: Supported Shells: - Bash - Zsh - Fish - PowerShell - Command Prompt (limited) Features: - Shell detection - Configuration file management - PATH manipulation - Auto-switch hooks - Wrapper function generation 8. Logger ( ) Purpose: Structured logging Key File: Log Levels: - Quiet (errors only) - Normal (standard output) - Verbose (debug information) Output Types: - Info, Success, Warning, Error - Progress indicators - Download/Extract/Verify status - Timing instrumentation 9. Progress ( ) Purpose: Progress bars for long operations Key File: Features: - Real-time progress updates - Download speed calculation - ETA estimation - Byte formatting - Multi-progress support 10. Symlink ( ) Purpose: Cross-platform symlink management Key File: Functions: - Create symlinks - Read symlink targets - Handle Windows/Unix differences 11. Utilities ( ) Purpose: Helper functions Key File: Helpers: - Byte size formatting (KB, MB, GB) - Duration formatting (3m12s, 2h05m) 12. Version ( ) Purpose: Build information Key File: Metadata: - Version number - Git commit hash - Build date - Builder information - Go version used Code Organization Principles 1. Separation of Concerns Each package has a single, well-defined responsibility: - CLI handles user interaction - Manager handles business logic - Downloader handles downloads - Config handles configuration 2. Dependency Direction Higher-level packages depend on lower-level packages, never the reverse. 3. Internal Packages All implementation code is in to prevent external imports. 4. Test Co-location Tests are placed alongside the code they test: - â†’ 5. Minimal main.go The entry point is minimal - just error handling and CLI invocation. Design Patterns 1. Singleton Pattern (Logger) 2. Strategy Pattern (Shell Integration) 3. Builder Pattern (Configuration) 4. Facade Pattern (Manager) Manager provides a simplified interface to complex subsystems: File Naming Conventions - Commands: (e.g., , ) - Tests: - Integration tests: - Interfaces: Defined in the main package file - Implementations: Separate files or inline in main file Import Organization Key Interfaces Shell Interface Logger Interface Singleton pattern, package-level functions: Data Structures Config VersionInfo Release Testing Structure Unit Tests - Located alongside source files - Test individual functions - Use table-driven tests Integration Tests - Tagged with - Test component interactions - Require Test Helpers Common patterns: - - Initialize test environment - - Clean up after tests - Table-driven tests for multiple cases Build Process Development Build Production Build Multi-Platform Build Error Handling Pattern Error Wrapping Always wrap errors with context using : See Also - Architecture - System design - Data Flow - How data moves - Dependencies - External packages - Developer Guide - Development setup --- Understanding the structure helps you navigate and contribute effectively! ðŸ—ºï¸
